+John O'Neill Like +Rogério Penna pointed out, that's an effect due to 
lighting, motion, and poor resolution/definition of the second generation 
filming of the broadcast on a television (not direct video). You can see 
the same camera in other games at the same football field. It was merely 
positioning itself on the zip wire for the next play. Cool effect! :)

of the world, they lose that sense. A lot of people also deny the fact that 
they can see ghosts/spirits. Some people also never develop that sixth 
sense. I can hear and see things, but not always. It's most common when 
your mind is at ease and not distracted, like a sports game.

side of the stadium. If you look closely you can see that the hight of the 
shadow is as the same as the sitting people, which can not be because a 
standing or running persons figure is longer than a sitting one, obviuosly. 
This is an elussion caused by the angle of the camera, the actuall shadow 
spreads on three seat rows. Thats why,also, it seems to run so fast,thats 
because the shadow is cast from afar.﻿

Skycam is a computer-controlled, stabilized, cable-suspended camera system. 
The system is maneuvered through three dimensions in the open space over a 
playing area of a stadium or arena by computer-controlled cable-drive 
system. It is responsible for bringing video game–like camera angles to 
television sports coverage. The camera package weighs less than 14 kg 
(30.86 lbs) and can travel at 13 m/s (29.08 mph).

+Jason Evans But how does it have legs? lol So someone was running and the 
camera affect made it look like a ghost? I guess we'll never know.

+thegonad78 You do bring up a very good point, I suppose it certainly could 
just be a convenient visual artifact. Unless someone uploads a better 
quality version (unlikely considering it's a Bolivian soccer game...) I 
surmise that nobody will ever know for sure! Camera is the most logical 
answer in this instance I suppose.

+Jason Evans Quite obviously a camera. Note the videos super-dooper extra 
high resolution of 240p.  The "running motion" is a compression artifact 
created by the foreground / background contrast changes as the camera moved 
across the screen when the original footage was compressed for uploading to 
Youtube. (note the "running motion" goes away when the background is all 
black)  If you were to be watching the actual broadcast on your television, 
there would be no "running motion" at all, just a moving camera.

+Strud
Yes, the people between 0:16 and 0:25 and the one walking in the opposite 
direction were the ones I was referring to, and in fact, if you look at 
other uploads of this video, there are lots of moving figures among the 
spectators, and on the field.  In one of them the "ghost" looks transparent 
and appears to pass *through* the bodies, and it would be very odd for a 
human to run as this figure does at exactly the same angle and speed the 
whole length of the bleachers.  Also, note how everyone seems to ignore the 
"ghost" as it passes them.  So I think a CGI "ghost" has been superimposed, 
but on a moving image rather than a still one as I thought earlier.  As for 
the "live", it appears in all the uploads of this video as here at the top 
right-hand as "Vivo" (i.e. live), and there would be nothing to stop 
someone sampling a recording of the live coverage and adding some CGI.  Or 
would there? I know nothing about copyright and TV live recordings.

+p123 there are people moving in the background as well. albeit very 
slowly: between 0:16 and 0:25 3 steps above the first three people this 
"ghost" walks past there is a man walking very very slowly in the opposite 
direction to the "ghost" along with all of the people on the stairs walking 
upwards at incredibly slow pace.

I think they may have just sped someone up and slowed everyone else down

Another small detail most would have overlooked because of the camera 
angle. where this "ghost" is running is slightly wider then the other 
spaces between the seats, denoting a walkway for people to move around more 
freely

+Samantha Jones and it can't have been, no matter where you are in the 
world if it's a sport show being streamed live it will always have the word 
"LIVE" with a red dot somewhere on the screen.

No, actually I missed the moving figures above.  I don't know how CGI works 
technically, but possibly they were CGI'd along with the "ghost" and the 
foreground figure and superimposed on the still, or somehow a bit of the 
original moving image was kept in, I really don't know.  

Edit: this was before I looked at the other uploads of this video on YT.

Oh sorry you mentioned them. I'm trying to understand how you can 
superimpose the moving person over a still picture, if there are people 
moving only a few rows above? I'm not denying your claim at all, I just 
don't know how that would be done.

What about those people walking in the bleachers, I think it's a row above 
the "ghost".
Wasn't this like live on a sports channel or something?

Sorry, one foreground figure, not two - it's the same one walking at normal 
speed and then slowed down.  I can't see the pixelated box in mine, 
but also the moving foreground figure and the "ghost" are the same size, 
which they shouldn't be, because of perspective, i.e. the "ghost" should be 
smaller because it is further back, and they both look a brownier-grey than 
the spectators.  Whoever made this didn't take into account that magnifying 
and slowing down the video would show up how the original had been tampered 
with.

Yeah and notice how the "ghost" is inside a (pixelated)box. Which kinda 
seems it was added to the picture afterwards.
+p123 Well spotted :)
